    • Constructor Detail

      • CustomAlert

        public CustomAlert(javafx.scene.control.Alert.AlertType alertType,
                   java.lang.String title,
                   java.lang.String contentText)
        Creates a working custom alert with proper css styling.

        Use like this: CustomAlert alert = new CustomAlert(Alert.AlertType.CONFIRMATION, "Title", "This is a test message."); if (alert.showAndWait().get() == ButtonType.OK) { System.out.println("Ok button pressed."); }

        Parameters:
        alertType - the type of alert
        title - the title of the window
        contentText - the text that the alert should contain

      • CustomAlert

        public CustomAlert(javafx.scene.control.Alert.AlertType alertType,
                   java.lang.String title,
                   java.lang.String contentText,
                   java.lang.String okButtonText,
                   java.lang.String cancelButtonText)
        Creates a working custom alert with proper css styling.

        Use like this: CustomAlert alert = new CustomAlert(Alert.AlertType.CONFIRMATION, "Title", "This is a test message.", "Okay", "Nope"); if (alert.showAndWait().get() == ButtonType.OK) { System.out.println("Ok button pressed."); }

        Parameters:
        alertType - the type of alert
        title - the title of the window
        contentText - the text that the alert should contain
        okButtonText - the text of the ok button
        cancelButtonText - the text of the cancel button

      • CustomAlert

        public CustomAlert(javafx.scene.control.Alert.AlertType alertType)
        Creates a working custom alert with proper css styling. Not recommended as it does not contain specific information!

        Use like this: CustomAlert alert = new CustomAlert(Alert.AlertType.CONFIRMATION); if (alert.showAndWait().get() == ButtonType.OK) { System.out.println("Ok button pressed."); }

        Parameters:
        alertType - the type of alert

        Initializes the window and adds styling.
